Following the example of Texas's criminal justice reform, this bill will bring much needed improvements to our criminal justice system. --> https://www.cruz.senate.gov/?p=press_release&id=4209
It makes common-sense reforms to prison conditions by promoting the compassionate release of elderly prisoners and prohibiting the shackling of pregnant women.

It lowers mandatory minimum sentences for non-violent drug offenders, creates new programs to reduce recidivism, and gives inmates an incentive to better themselves with those programs through earned time credits.
With these changes, this bill gives non-violent offenders a better chance at rejoining society while keeping violent offenders behind bars.

With these necessary improvements, I believe the Senate should take up and pass this important legislation. I look forward to working hand-in-hand with the White House and the bill sponsors to make sure that happens.

I‚Äôm happy to report that, after working closely with the White House and the sponsors of this bill, they have decided to accept my amendment. This new version of the bill resolves my concerns, and is one that I wholeheartedly support and cosponsor.
At the same time, I do not believe we should be granting early release to violent offenders. That is why I drafted an amendment that would exclude violent offenders from being released early.
I have long supported criminal justice reform. I believe in reducing mandatory minimum sentences for non-violent drug offenders, and providing greater opportunities for offenders to be rehabilitated.

I can‚Äôt begin to imagine what it would‚Äôve been like to have to decide between going hungry and having my mother at home, but that‚Äôs the choice other families may have to make if Trump‚Äôs proposal gets implemented.
The goal of his new rule is clear: to vilify immigrants, scaring them away from getting the care they desperately need in an attempt to push‚Äîeven starve‚Äîthem out of this country.
Right now, POTUS is trying to change the law to force immigrant families to choose b/w staying eligible for perm. residency & receiving lifesaving public benefits like SNAP & Medicaid.

In the end, we survived. We scraped by. And my mother was able to join us (later becoming a proud U.S. citizen). But if President Trump has his way, the same might not be true for countless other scared, struggling families.
I still remember going to the grocery store and counting out our last five $1 food stamps to buy as much bread and bologna as possible‚Äîthen praying we‚Äôd have enough to last the week.

Having a warm meal at night quickly went from being a given to a godsend. I still remember the hours my dad spent walking from payphone to payphone, hoping to find enough spare change for me and my brother to be able to afford the 25-cent school lunch the next day.

When I was a teenager, my dad lost his job, sending our family spiraling into poverty. My father, brother and I soon moved from SE Asia to Hawaii‚Äîbut my mom was forced to stay back as she wasn‚Äôt yet a U.S. citizen

As the daughter of an immigrant and someone who depended on food stamps to survive, I refuse to stay silent as the Trump Admin tries to punish immigrant families by changing the ‚ÄúPublic Charge‚Äù rule.
